result.markdown:
# Traditional Covariates ## Preamble ::: {.panel-tabset} ### Chapter Objective Using only traditional covariates, the objective of this chapter is to propose various statistical models for estimation and variable selection to predict the number of claims. More specifically, the following model families will be examined: - Basic GLM, - GLM family, including elastic-net, - XGBoost. As mentioned in the theory review chapter, to compare models and strike a balance between bias and variance while avoiding overfitting, an interesting approach is to assess the prediction quality of models when applied to new data. The following R script presents a function for calculating various scores: To analyze severities, we define two scores: 1) the negative loglikelihood based on the Gamma distribution with shape parameter = 1/phi and scale = (mu)(phi), where mu is the expected value and phi is the dispersion parameter; 2) the mean squared error (MSE) divided by 1,000,000. ::: {.cell} ::: ### Packages The analyses in this chapter will be conducted using the same data as in the previous chapter. Here is the list of packages that will be used: ::: {.cell} ::: ### Data ::: {.cell} ::: ::: ## Basic GLM Models ::: {.panel-tabset} ### Single intercept A baseline model corresponding to a Generalized Linear Model (GLM) with intercept and predicting for each contract only the observed mean multiplied by the observed frequency is used as a point of comparison. ::: {#tbl-Pscore_base_sev .cell tbl-cap='Prediction scores for the base model (severity)'} ::: {.cell-output-display} \begin{table} \centering \begin{tabular}{c|c|c} \hline Fold & Sc.log & Sc.MSE\\ \hline 1 & 9.28096 & 48.72725\\ \hline 2 & 9.28378 & 21.80556\\ \hline 3 & 9.30844 & 31.17175\\ \hline 4 & 9.34049 & 30.61554\\ \hline 5 & 9.26105 & 18.96634\\ \hline Total & 9.29513 & 30.43693\\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{table} ::: ::: The model is, therefore, estimated on the entire *train* database, and the predictions are made on the *test* database, which was not used during the calibration phase. ::: {#tbl-Pscore_basetest_sev_tel .cell tbl-cap='Prediction scores for the base model (testing set) (severity)'} ::: {.cell-output-display} \begin{table} \centering \begin{tabular}{c|c|c} \hline Model & Sc.log & Sc.MSE\\ \hline Base & 9.29504 & 21.82679\\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{table} ::: ::: ### Categorical covariates A first regression approach is attempted using only the traditional categorical variables, namely: - Gender, - Marital status, - Vehicle usage, - Region. Even though territory should also be considered since it consists of more than fifty different factors, it will not be integrated into the model immediately. As we saw in the overview of variables in a previous section, the insured gender did not appear to be an important variable for predicting the number of claims. This GLM approach confirms this observation. Therefore, this variable is excluded from the model. In the table below, we can see the impact of adding traditional variables on the prediction quality. Below are the prediction scores of the model with all categorical covariates. As expected, the addition of segmentation variables improves the prediction scores compared to the simple baseline model with only an intercept. ::: {#tbl-Pscore_GLM1_sev .cell tbl-cap='Prediction scores for the GLM1 model (severity)'} ::: {.cell-output-display} \begin{table} \centering \begin{tabular}{c|c|c} \hline Fold & Sc.log & Sc.MSE\\ \hline 1 & 9.26014 & 47.85313\\ \hline 2 & 9.25790 & 22.01984\\ \hline 3 & 9.28552 & 31.20756\\ \hline 4 & 9.31168 & 30.29863\\ \hline 5 & 9.23947 & 18.59595\\ \hline Total & 9.27110 & 30.17198\\ \hline Improvement & -0.02403 & -0.26495\\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{table} ::: ::: ::: {#tbl-Pscore_basetest2_sev .cell tbl-cap='Prediction scores for the GLM model with traditional covariates (testing set) (severity)'} ::: {.cell-output-display} \begin{table} \centering \begin{tabular}{c|c|c} \hline Model & Sc.log & Sc.MSE\\ \hline Base & 9.29504 & 21.82679\\ \hline GLM (trad.) & 9.27546 & 21.77177\\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{table} ::: ::: ### Estimated Parameters The table below shows the estimators obtained for the GLM-Gamma approach and compares them with the baseline model having only an intercept. ::: {#tbl-CoeffGLM_sev .cell tbl-cap='Estimated parameters for the GLM1 model (severity)'} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
  M Claim M Claim
Predictors Estimates CI p Estimates CI p
(Intercept) 8.12 8.07 – 8.18 <0.001 7.76 7.46 – 8.09 <0.001
Insured sex [Male] 0.07 -0.04 – 0.18 0.196
Marital [Single] 0.14 0.03 – 0.26 0.013
Car use [Commute] 0.28 -0.03 – 0.56 0.061
Car use [Farmer] -0.93 -1.65 – -0.06 0.019
Car use [Private] -0.01 -0.32 – 0.27 0.936
Region [Urban] 0.12 -0.03 – 0.26 0.112
Observations 3091 3091
R2 Nagelkerke 0.000 0.045
````` ::: ::: ::: ## GLM-Net Some traditional continuous segmentation variables are available: - Credit score, - Age of the insured, - Age of the vehicle, - Number of claim-free years. Furthermore, the territory is also treated as a continuous variable. An approach using Generalized Additive Models (GAM) theory will first be introduced for all these continuous variables. This will allow us to observe the general form of the covariate to explain the number of claims. A parametric form will then be proposed to achieve the best possible correspondence with the spline obtained by the GAM. ### Parametric transformation of continuous covariates ::: {.panel-tabset} ### Credit Score The first covariate studied is the credit score. We include all categorical variables in the analysis and apply a spline approach with a GAM. The spline analysis indicates that the following parametric form appears to be appropriate for capturing the relationship: $$s(Credit.Score) \approx Credit.Score + Credit.Score^2$$ ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Smoothing of the credit score (severity)](severityVarTrad_files/figure-pdf/fig-CS_GAM_sev-1.pdf){#fig-CS_GAM_sev} ::: ::: ### Age of the insured A spline to examine the relationship between the age of the insured and the claim deverity has also been produced. The most appropriate parametric form is as follows: $$s(Insured.age) \approx Insured.age + Insured.age^2$$ ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Smoothing of the age of the insured (severity)](severityVarTrad_files/figure-pdf/fig-IA_GAM_sev-1.pdf){#fig-IA_GAM_sev} ::: ::: ### Age of the car The link between the response variable and the car age is approximated by $$s(Car.age) \approx Car.age + Car.age^2 + Car.age^3$$ ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Smoothing of the age of the car (severity)](severityVarTrad_files/figure-pdf/fig-CA_GAM_sev-1.pdf){#fig-CA_GAM_sev} ::: ::: ### Years without claims Finally, the link between the response variable and the number of year(s) without claims is best approximated by $$s(Years.noclaims) \approx Years.noclaims + Years.noclaims^2 + Years.noclaims^3$$ ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Smoothing of years without claim (severity)](severityVarTrad_files/figure-pdf/fig-YNC_GAM_sev-1.pdf){#fig-YNC_GAM_sev} ::: ::: ### Territory We proceed with the covariate Territory as we did for the analysis of the frequency. The parametric function is: $$s(terr.code) \approx terr.code + terr.code^2 + terr.code^3$$ ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Smoothing of the territories (encoded) (severity)](severityVarTrad_files/figure-pdf/fig-terrcode_GAM_sev-1.pdf){#fig-terrcode_GAM_sev} ::: ::: ::: ### Fitting the GLM-Net model ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.panel-tabset} ### Optimal value The parameters of the GLM-net were calibrated using cross-validation to obtain the model hyperparameters. Using these values, we can calculate the prediction scores of the model based on all covariates. ::: {#tbl-Pscore_GLMnet1_sev .cell tbl-cap='Prediction scores for the GLM-net model (alpha=1) (severity)'} ::: {.cell-output-display} \begin{table} \centering \begin{tabular}{c|c|c} \hline Fold & Sc.log & Sc.MSE\\ \hline 1 & 9.20427 & 45.11001\\ \hline 2 & 9.22953 & 20.98561\\ \hline 3 & 9.24011 & 28.93837\\ \hline 4 & 9.27740 & 28.99576\\ \hline 5 & 9.21277 & 17.93211\\ \hline Total & 9.23286 & 28.56121\\ \hline Improvement & -0.06228 & -1.87573\\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{table} ::: ::: The same model can be used to compute the scores on the *test* set. ::: {#tbl-Pscore_basetest3_sev_tel .cell tbl-cap='Prediction scores for the GLM-net model (testing set)'} ::: {.cell-output-display} \begin{table} \centering \begin{tabular}{c|c|c} \hline Model & Sc.log & Sc.MSE\\ \hline Base & 9.29504 & 21.82679\\ \hline GLM (trad.) & 9.27546 & 21.77177\\ \hline LASSO (optimal) & 9.23357 & 20.23523\\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{table} ::: ::: ### Parsimonious model Instead of using the optimal value of the penalty $\lambda$ in the elastic-net approach, it is often advised to use a penalty value located at one standard error ($\lambda_{1se}$). This helps to obtain a more parsimonious model. The prediction scores of such a model are displayed below. ::: {#tbl-Pscore_GLMnet2_sev .cell tbl-cap='Prediction scores for the GLM-net model (alpha=1) (severity)'} ::: {.cell-output-display} \begin{table} \centering \begin{tabular}{c|c|c} \hline Fold & Sc.log & Sc.MSE\\ \hline 1 & 9.21249 & 45.73294\\ \hline 2 & 9.22998 & 20.68548\\ \hline 3 & 9.24605 & 29.09385\\ \hline 4 & 9.28279 & 29.08124\\ \hline 5 & 9.21318 & 17.88075\\ \hline Total & 9.23698 & 28.66605\\ \hline Improvement & -0.05816 & -1.77089\\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{table} ::: ::: The same model can be used to compute the scores on the *test* set. ::: {#tbl-Pscore_basetest3_sev_tel2 .cell tbl-cap='Prediction scores for the GLM-net model (testing set)'} ::: {.cell-output-display} \begin{table} \centering \begin{tabular}{c|c|c} \hline Model & Sc.log & Sc.MSE\\ \hline Base & 9.29504 & 21.82679\\ \hline GLM (trad.) & 9.27546 & 21.77177\\ \hline LASSO (optimal) & 9.23357 & 20.23523\\ \hline LASSO (parsimonious) & 9.23729 & 20.21870\\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{table} ::: ::: ### Categorical covariates For categorical variables, the relativity values obtained for both GLM-net approaches are displayed below. ::: {#fig-GLMnetcat_sev .cell layout-nrow="2" layout-ncol="2"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Sex of the insured](severityVarTrad_files/figure-pdf/fig-GLMnetcat_sev-1.pdf){#fig-GLMnetcat_sev-1} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Marital status of the insured](severityVarTrad_files/figure-pdf/fig-GLMnetcat_sev-2.pdf){#fig-GLMnetcat_sev-2} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Car use](severityVarTrad_files/figure-pdf/fig-GLMnetcat_sev-3.pdf){#fig-GLMnetcat_sev-3} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Region](severityVarTrad_files/figure-pdf/fig-GLMnetcat_sev-4.pdf){#fig-GLMnetcat_sev-4} ::: Interprétation des variables catégorielles du GLM-net (severity) ::: ### Continuous covariates As with categorical variables, the relativities obtained are illustrated below for continuous variables. ::: {#fig-GLMnet_sev .cell layout-nrow="3" layout-ncol="2"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Credit Score](severityVarTrad_files/figure-pdf/fig-GLMnet_sev-1.pdf){#fig-GLMnet_sev-1} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Annal Miles Drive](severityVarTrad_files/figure-pdf/fig-GLMnet_sev-2.pdf){#fig-GLMnet_sev-2} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Age of the car](severityVarTrad_files/figure-pdf/fig-GLMnet_sev-3.pdf){#fig-GLMnet_sev-3} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Age of the insured](severityVarTrad_files/figure-pdf/fig-GLMnet_sev-4.pdf){#fig-GLMnet_sev-4} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Years without claim](severityVarTrad_files/figure-pdf/fig-GLMnet_sev-5.pdf){#fig-GLMnet_sev-5} ::: Interprétation des variables continues du GLM-net (severity) ::: ::: ## XGBoost As we did for the analysis of claim frequency, we also consider the XGBoost approach for claim severity. We utilized Bayesian optimization to find the hyperparameters of the model. ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.panel-tabset} ### Prediction Scores Using the hyperparameters we identified, we can calculate the model's prediction scores. The obtained scores demonstrate a notable enhancement compared to alternative approaches evaluated. ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {#tbl-Pscore_XGBoost_sev .cell tbl-cap='Prediction scores for the XGBoost model (severity)' hash='severityVarTrad_cache/pdf/tbl-Pscore_XGBoost_sev_04fb4358291c58c92438d11f50783154'} ::: {.cell-output-display} \begin{table} \centering \begin{tabular}{c|c|c} \hline Fold & Sc.log & Sc.MSE\\ \hline 1 & 9.35734 & 44.35244\\ \hline 2 & 9.14014 & 20.12582\\ \hline 3 & 9.21035 & 28.22455\\ \hline 4 & 9.23525 & 28.30773\\ \hline 5 & 9.09730 & 17.68123\\ \hline Total & 9.20981 & 27.90189\\ \hline Improvement & -0.08533 & -2.53505\\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{table} ::: ::: The same model can be used to compute the scores on the *test* set. We also observe that the XGBoost approach is the most effective. ::: {#tbl-Pscore_XGBoost_correction333_sev_tel .cell tbl-cap='Prediction scores for the XGBoost model with traditional covariates (severity)'} ::: {.cell-output-display} \begin{table} \centering \begin{tabular}{c|c|c} \hline Model & Sc.log & Sc.MSE\\ \hline Base & 9.29504 & 21.82679\\ \hline GLM (trad.) & 9.27546 & 21.77177\\ \hline LASSO (optimal) & 9.23357 & 20.23523\\ \hline LASSO (parsimonious) & 9.23729 & 20.21870\\ \hline XGBoost & 9.19011 & 20.06725\\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{table} ::: ::: ### Variables Importance The following graph depicts the most crucial variables in the XGBoost model. ::: {#tbl-VI_XGBoost_sev .cell tbl-cap='Variables importance for the XGBoost model (severity)'} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](severityVarTrad_files/figure-pdf/tbl-VI_XGBoost_sev-1.pdf) ::: ::: :::
